column1: Naro-Fominsk (Russian: На́ро-Фоми́нск) is a town and the administrative center of Naro-Fominsky District in Moscow Oblast
column4: 70 kilometers (43 mi) southwest from Moscow. Population: 64

column1: The Fominskoye village was first mentioned in chronicles in 1339
column2: while it was under the rule of Ivan Kalita. Napoleon's Grande Armée passed through Fominskoye on its retreat from Moscow in 1812. The modern Naro-Fominsk was established as an urban-type settlement as a result of the merger of the villages of Fominskoye
column3: Malaya Nara and Malkovo in 1925. Town status was granted to it in 1926. The town was severely damaged during World War II after Nazi Germany forces destroyed 687 buildings and a textile factory during the Battle of Moscow in 1941. Western part of Naro-Fominsk was occupied from October 21 to December 26
column4: 1941. Naro-Fominsk was liberated by the 33rd army under the command Mikhail Grigoryevich Yefremov.

column1: Naro-Fominsk silk factory was the first in the USSR to produce fabric "Bologna" in the early 1960s.
Within the framework of administrative divisions
column2: Naro-Fominsk serves as the administrative center of Naro-Fominsky District. As an administrative division
column5: incorporated within Naro-Fominsky District as the Town of Naro-Fominsk. As a municipal division
column6: the Town of Naro-Fominsk is incorporated within Naro-Fominsky Municipal District as Naro-Fominsk Urban Settlement.

column1: The Moscow–Kyiv railway passes through the town.
The town is home to the 4th Guards Kantemirovskaya Tank Division
column2: part of the Western Military District.
